key_insight: eMOSAIC combines multimodal molecular and protein information with per-sample out-of-distribution (OOD) uncertainty estimates to substantially improve binding affinity prediction for compounds that act on multiple targets (polypharmacology). This lets models flag unreliable predictions and prioritize trustworthy candidate-target pairs.
problem_solved: Accurate binding affinity prediction for polypharmacology is hampered by multimodal inputs and out-of-distribution examples; the paper addresses unreliable predictions by providing individual uncertainty quantification to detect and mitigate OOD failures.
method: Integrate multimodal representations (chemical features, protein descriptors/structures, and contextual assay metadata) into a unified prediction model.
Produce calibrated, per-sample uncertainty estimates that identify OOD compoundâ€“protein pairs and adjust or reject low-confidence affinity predictions.
Use uncertainty-aware decision rules to improve ranking and selection of polypharmacological candidates (reducing false positives and guiding experiments).
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners a practical pipeline to make binding affinity models more reliable and actionable in drug discovery, enabling safer prioritization of multitarget compounds and reducing wasted experimental effort.
visual_elements: Schematic showing multimodal inputs (compound structure, protein sequence/structure, assay context) converging into the eMOSAIC model

paper_title: Multimodal out-of-distribution individual uncertainty quantification enhances binding affinity prediction for polypharmacology
paper_authors: Amitesh Badkul, Li Xie, Shuo Zhang, Lei Xie
